intro: Gratiola viscosa var. drummondii, commonly known as Drummond's stickyweed, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Scrophulariaceae family, which includes many species with showy flowers and specialized pollination mechanisms. The plant is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and small, tubular flowers that often have a distinctive pink or purple hue. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions through its succulent-like stems and deep root system. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscapic gardens.
